entries.title: Dash pattern and stress-linked RR spikes
entries.notes: Observed dash-to-rest behavior after bathroom and water visits. Respiratory rate rose to about 40-44 after exertion and settled toward 36 with rest; sleeping baseline in nearby windows was around 28-32. Pattern looked stress/exertion-linked rather than persistent respiratory decline.

entries.title: Storm stress, tremors, and litter-box lingering
entries.notes: Significant overnight storm stress with repeated litter-box visits and crouched lingering posture. Morning RR was around 32-36, then rose to about 40 after fluid session with tremors and less rhythmic breathing, later easing back during sleep. Drooling and nausea cues persisted later in day.

entries.title: Morning stable window with mild oral signal
entries.notes: Morning snapshot was relatively stable with sleeping/rest RR around 28-32 and overnight urination about three times. No active drooling but thick saliva and one faint blood-tinged saliva episode were noted, then resolved. Activity remained low-energy but engaged outdoors.

entries.title: Post-fluid withdrawal and decompression
entries.notes: After daily fluids, she retreated and avoided interaction, consistent with treatment aversion/decompression behavior. Following uninterrupted nap, RR returned around 32-36. Eating continued in the broader day window despite handling sensitivity and intermittent touch reactivity.

entries.title: Good window with persistent oral-eating friction
entries.notes: Relative good window: sleeping RR around 20-24, calm behavior, grooming, and ongoing food intake. Kibble interest existed but tolerance remained poor, suggesting oral discomfort; soupy food was better tolerated. Morning nausea pill was refused/spit at least once.

entries.title: Cachexia concern and nighttime restlessness
entries.notes: Overnight check emphasized severe thin body condition and emotional concern; weight was about 5.98 lb. Kibble remained difficult while soft/soupy food strategy continued. This reflected ongoing catabolic burden despite preserved interest in intake opportunities.

entries.title: Tongue-use concern with gum-bleeding clarification
entries.notes: Morning observation: strong hunger/thirst approach behavior but reduced tongue-use during attempts to eat/drink. Faint blood was seen then resolved. Follow-up context suggests some blood likely originated from fragile gums, including light bleeding during routine tooth-brushing, while oral discomfort remained clinically relevant.

entries.title: Pool incident with transient right-leg redness
entries.notes: After a brief pool fall/swim event, right leg skin appeared red to light-purple transiently. Later checks showed weight-bearing on both legs and similar light-pink paw-pad tone bilaterally, favoring localized irritation/minor trauma over severe perfusion failure. Continued short-interval observation planned.
